item.title: Cyprus Gets New Bailout Deal
item.description: Cyprus secured a bailout from its international creditors early Monday, ending a week of financial panic that threatened to see the small island nation become the first government to leave the euro zone.

item.title: Kerry Visits Afghanistan
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Afghanistan, a trip that comes after confrontational rhetoric from President Karzai.

item.title: U.K. Investigates Russian Tycoon's Death
item.description: British police on Sunday ordered an autopsy to determine the cause of Boris Berezovsky's death.

item.title: African Nation's Chief Flees Rebels
item.description: Deadly clashes between rebels and foreign troops protecting the Central African Republic government forced President François Bozizé to flee, consigning the coup-prone country to an uncertain future.

item.title: U.S. Prods Iraq to Stop Arms to Syria
item.description: John Kerry urged Iraq's leaders to halt Iranian overflights of weapons and fighters heading to Syria.

item.title: U.S. Hands Prison Over to Afghans
item.description: The U.S. military gave control of its last detention facility in Afghanistan to Kabul, a year after the two sides initially agreed on the transfer.

item.title: Hong Kong Maids Lose Residency Fight
item.description: Hong Kong's top court ruled that foreign maids aren't entitled to permanent residency rights, dealing a blow to the thousands of domestic helpers—mostly Filipino and Indonesian—in a case that has divided the city.

item.title: Syrian Rebel Leader Wounded in Blast
item.description: A rebel military leader who was among the first to call openly for armed insurrection against President Bashar al-Assad was wounded by a bomb planted in his car in eastern Syria, rebels and activists said.

item.title: Cameron Hardens Immigration Line
item.description: U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron toughened his stance on immigration with measures to restrict foreigners' access to state support for unemployment, housing and health.

item.title: Vietnam Will Cut Rates
item.description: The State Bank of Vietnam said it will cut its policy rates for the first time this year, seeking to boost economic growth as inflation shows signs of easing.

item.title: Australian Leader Shuffles Cabinet
item.description: Australia's embattled Prime Minister Julia Gillard appointed a former mining company executive as the country's resources minister in a wider reshuffle of top positions.

item.title: Syrian Opposition Leader Resigns
item.description: The leadership of Syria's interim government-in-exile was in disarray on Sunday after its president resigned and the rebel's main fighting force declined to recognize its prime minister days after he was elected.

item.title: South Africa Trade Hits Bump
item.description: South Africa joined BRICS to tighten ties with the world's largest emerging markets. Today, the embrace from outsize competitors, particularly China, is suffocating South African manufacturers, executives say.

item.title: Calm Restored in Myanmar
item.description: Underscoring the Myanmar military's continuing importance even as it takes a back seat in political affairs, the army quieted days of violence in the central Mandalay town of Meikhtila, rocked last week by sectarian riots.

item.title: Pakistan's Musharraf Returns
item.description: Former Pakistani president Pervez Musharraf returned from self-imposed exile, seeking to recapture a place in politics.

item.title: France Confirms al Qaeda Leader Killed
item.description: The French government confirmed Saturday that Abdelhamid Abou Zeid was killed late last month during combat in northern Mali.

item.title: CIA Expands Role in Syria
item.description: The Central Intelligence Agency is expanding its role in the campaign against the Syrian regime by feeding intelligence to rebel fighters, U.S. officials said.

item.title: A Meeting of Popes
item.description: Pope Francis met with his predecessor Benedict XVI, a historic and potentially problematic melding of the papacies that has never before confronted the Catholic Church.

item.title: Beijing's Spring Snowfall
item.description: Beijing residents woke up Wednesday, the first official day of spring in the Chinese traditional calendar, to a city blanketed in white after an overnight snow storm.

item.title: Diana's Million-Dollar Wardrobe
item.description: Kerry Taylor Auctions expects to raise more than £800,000 pounds ($1.2 million) with the sale of 10 dresses belonging to Britain's late Princess Diana, which are up for auction Tuesday.

item.title: Wu Led Village to Become China's Richest
item.description: Wu Renbao, who used "capitalism with Chinese characteristics" to turn a farm community into what is now known in China as the country's richest village, died of lung cancer.

item.title: Photos of the Day: March 24
item.description: In today's pictures, Hindu widows celebrate Holi, a father and child admire cherry blossoms in Tokyo, girls dance an Irish jig in Boston, and more.

item.title: Photos of the Week: March 17-22
item.description: In this week's photos, a man holds his head at a rally in Cyprus, a man walks through a park in Berlin, a bodysurfer punches through a wave in Hawaii, and more.

item.title: Arise! Arise! The British Are…Acting!
item.description: On big and small screens, the juicy Yank parts are going to people with names like Day-Lewis. How to fight back.

item.title: Brains of Animal Kingdom
item.description: Research shows that we have grossly underestimated both the scope and the scale of animal intelligence. Primatologist Frans de Waal on memory-champ chimps, tool-using elephants and rats capable of empathy.
